dialogues.text: A city in India. A crowd of street-children scatters out the way as a small, sixties-style, black and yellow taxi speeds up a narrow road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TAXI. DAY
dialogues.text: The driver grips the steering wheel tightly. He wears a b turban, large, plastic sunglasses, and a determined look. fifty-year-old businessman in a grey suit rides in the ba He checks his watch and stares out the window, anxious. A meter which looks like a slot-machine is mounted on the l side of the hood outside the windshield. The taxi shoots along the edge of a market. It cuts in- between three bicycles and a buzzing scooter with a famil four on it. The mother in a red sari rides side-saddle. T taxi flies past two rickshaws stacked with table linens a dodges a cow walking in the street.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DEPOT. DAY
dialogues.text: The taxi skids around a corner and -- with one of the rea doors already swinging open -- slides to a stop at the entrance to a train station. Vendors on the sidewalk sell fruits, vegetables, spices, pottery, textiles, etc. A man a stand makes fresh-squeezed sugar-cane juice. The fifty-year-old man jumps out of the car carrying two Samsonite suitcases. The driver shouts something after hi Hindi. The fifty-year-old man looks back at him uncertain without stopping. He sprints into the building.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DEPOT. DAY
dialogues.text: The fifty-year-old man runs weaving through a bustling cr of people buying tickets and waiting on benches, past por in red turbans carrying piles of baggage on their heads, onto the platform.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLATFORM. DAY
dialogues.text: Bells are ringing. Wheels are clacking. Smoke is blowing. train is already pulling out, and the fifty-year-old man alongside the tracks behind it. A teenager with a faint moustache and a half-unbuttoned s watches calmly from a deck at the rear of the caboose. He holds a cricket bat at his side. A sign above his head re The Darjeeling Limited with a picture of a running elepha below it. Script provided for educational purposes. He clenches his fists begins to lose ground. He yells over the sound of the engine’s whistle -- but the train pulls further ahead. A second runner appears behind the fifty-year-old man. He thirty-five. He is dressed in a navy blue, wool suit with light blue shirt. He wears slightly tinted aviator sungla which sit crookedly on his nose. He carries an old, beate suitcase with a jungle pattern print of small cheetahs, elephants, zebras, palm trees, and pelicans all over it a the initials J.L.W. stencilled onto it. He sprints past t fifty-year-old man, heads full-steam to the back of the train, throws his suitcase onto the deck ahead of him, an leaps on-board, looping his elbow around a pole. He is Pe Whitman. Peter looks at the teenager. The teenager squints at him. They both turn to look back at the fifty-year-old man, wh slowing down with an expression of sad frustration on his face. Peter watches him sympathetically. Peter picks up his suitcase and goes into the train.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR. DAY
dialogues.text: Peter walks quickly through two cars and enters a third. pulls a ticket out of his coat pocket and checks the numb next to each compartment door as he goes down the corrido He stops at one and double-checks his ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number plate on the wall. It reads 40/41. Thin cardboar strips inserted in slots have F. Whitman, P. Whitman, and Whitman typed on them.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COMPARTMENT 40/41. DAY
dialogues.text: Peter slides open the door, goes inside, and shuts the do behind him. He sets down his suitcase and sits on a bench seat across from a sleeping twenty-five-year-old man with side of his face pressed against the window and his mouth open. He has a Beatles-type moustache and wears a grey, w suit with a black shirt. He is Jack Whitman. Four old, beaten-up suitcases of various sizes, plus a matching trunk and two duffel bags, all with the same jun pattern print and the initials J.L.W. stencilled onto the sit piled on racks and shelves around the small compartme On a fold-out table, there is a pitcher of water, an empt glass, and a small manila note book with a pen tucked int Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca its spine. A transistor radio plays Indian music at a lo volume on the windowsill. A small, metal fan whirs on the ceiling. Peter takes a foil strip-pack of green-striped pills labe Hypno-Aid with instructions on it in Hindi out of a yello plastic sack. He pours himself a glass of water and swall a pill. He is still breathing hard. He lifts up his glass to look out from under them and says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Wake up, Jack. Jack opens his eyes and closes his mouth. He sits up and looks at Peter. He blinks a few times and clears his thro He laughs. Peter laughs. They both take out cigarettes an light them. Jack says significantly, raising his eyebrows

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Have you seen Francis? Peter hesitates, curious. The compartment door slides ope forty-year-old man in a light brown, wool suit with a yel shirt stands in the hallway holding a tray of whiskey highballs (Irish whiskey over ice with club soda and a le twist). He has gauze pads over his temples with medical t holding them in place and white bandages wrapped all arou his head. Both of his eyes are blackened and swollen, and has two sets of stitches plus numerous bruises, scratches scabs, and three small bandages on his face. He leans slightly on a bamboo cane. He is Francis Whitman. He says softly:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Hello, Peter. Peter looks startled at the condition of Francis’ face. Francis smiles and laughs. He comes into the compartment, shuts the door behind him, and sits down. He hands one of whiskey highballs to Jack and one to Peter. They all laug Francis lights a cigarette. They drink their drinks quick There is a knock on the door. Francis slides it open. A thirty-year-old man with a beard stands in the corridor with a hole-puncher in his hand. He wears a green silk tu and a Nehru jacket with Chief Steward embroidered onto it

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF STEWARD
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. Whitman? Francis, Peter, and Jack nod.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF STEWARD
dialogues.text: May I see your tickets, please? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Francis, Peter, and Jack take their tickets out of their pockets and hand them to the chief steward. The chief ste clicks the tickets with his hole puncher and snaps them i a clip above the door. He points at a small No Smoking si over the sink.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF STEWARD
dialogues.text: No smoking, please. Francis, Peter, and Jack hesitate. Francis awkwardly crac open the window. They all quickly take a last few puffs a blow smoke out before they flick their cigarettes away in the countryside. The chief steward looks annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF STEWARD
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard. The chief steward goes out the door. A twenty-five year-o girl in a pale green, silk sari-uniform comes in with a t of pale green drinks in little cups. She has long eyelash and a red dot on her forehead. She wears tortoise-shell glasses. She smiles and says:

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: Sweet lime? Francis, Peter, and Jack stare at the stewardess.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I'll have one.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That sounds good. The stewardess sets three cups of juice onto the table. S dips her fingertip into a little, metal bowl of red powde and carefully presses a dot onto each of their foreheads. Francis' dot goes on his bandages. The stewardess goes back into the corridor, looks at Jack an instant, and shuts the door. Francis, Peter, and Jack drink their cups of juice. They look pleased. Francis say suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Let’s go get a drink and smoke a cigarette. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, Peter, and Jack walk quickly through the train, balancing against the walls and windows as the cars jolt and forth. Francis limps and swings his cane. They light cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I want to start by thanking you both for being here. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: You’re the two most important people in the world to me. I’ve never said that before, but it’s true, and I want you both to know it. Francis opens a sliding door and stops in-between two car The sound of the wind and clacking wheels is extremely lo He yells over the noise:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I love you, Peter!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (moved but uneasy) Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I love you, Jack!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (moved but curious) I love you, too! Francis opens the door to the next car and leads Peter an Jack up the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: How'd it get to this? Why haven't we spoken in a year? Let's make an agreement.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: A.) I want us to become brothers again like we used to be, and for us to find ourselves and bond with each other. Can we agree to that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: B.) I want us to make this trip a spiritual journey, and for us to seek the unknown and learn about it. Can we agree to that?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: c.) I want us to be completely open and say yes to everything -- even if it's shocking and painful. Can we agree to that? Peter and Jack hesitate. Francis continues:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I had Brendan make us an itinerary. Francis takes a small manila envelope out of his pocket a unties a string to open it. He hands Peter and Jack each small, laminated piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A type-written card with Travel Itinerary printed across top and a detailed list of trains, times, hotels, cities, phone numbers, etc. below. Peter and Jack look puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who’s Brendan? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: My new assistant. He’s going to give us an updated schedule under our doors every morning of all the temples and spiritual places we need to see and expedite the hotels and transportation and everything.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (puzzled) How’s he going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I had him bring a printer and a laminating machine.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (more puzzled) Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (slightly defensive) In a way, it, actually, doesn’t matter. He's in a different compartment on another part of the train, but we never see him -- ever. Peter and Jack look around the corridor, confused. Jack starts to ask something, but Francis interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: So that’s more or less it. Does it sound OK to you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It sounds good. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. It sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Do you have any questions? Peter lifts up his glasses and looks out from under them. says brightly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: OK. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What happened to your face? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clouds, stars, and a moon are painted on the ceiling. The room is filled with people seated for dinner. Waiters in green, silk uniforms rush around taking orders. Francis, Peter, and Jack drink whiskey highballs. They share a tab with a grey-haired man dressed in a white tunic reading a Hindi newspaper. There is a bowl of nuts in front of them Peter listens with his glasses lifted up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I only remember certain details, but from what I've been able to reconstruct, it was raining, and I was going about fifty miles an hour when I went into a corner, did some wrong steering, and suddenly -- (snaps his fingers) -- skidded off the road, slammed into a ditch, and catapulted fifty feet through the air. Little bits of glass and particles were stinging me as I flew. For a second, there was just silence. Then the bike crashed to the ground, exploded, and caught on fire, and I smashed into the side of the hill with my face. I was going home. I live alone right now. Anyway, two joggers ran over and dug out all the dirt that was jammed inside my mouth and my nose and my ears (my heart had stopped, and my brain had stopped, so I was technically dead, at this point), and they did all the procedures exactly right, as a result of which I’m still alive. Peter and Jack look deeply impressed. Francis stands up. His voice cracks slightly as he says: Francis hugs Peter tightly. He hugs Jack tightly. He sits

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Boy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: The first thing I thought of after I woke up was: I wish Peter and Jack were here. back down. He takes a deep breath. He says quietly to Pet Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: Have you heard anything from Mom?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Have you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Me, neither. A girl's voice snaps sharply in Hindi at the other end of dining car. Jack turns to look. The stewardess stands amo the waiters and the chief steward with two empty champagn bottles and a bucket of half-melted ice under her arm. Sh argues with the chief steward at a whisper in Hindi. Peter squints, mutters, and rubs his temples. He takes th strip-pack out of his yellow plastic sack again. He pops another pill and swallows it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Some kind of Indian muscle-relaxer. I got it at the pharmacy next to the train station. You don't need a prescription here. Jack nods. He takes out a bottle of purple syrup labelled Narco-Cough with instructions in Hindi on it out of his o yellow plastic sack. He pours a capful, drinks it, then t a swig directly from the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A type of Indian flu medicine. It's got a tranquilizer in it. Francis nods. He takes a glass vial of amber liquid label Opio-Sedate with instructions in Hindi on it out of his o yellow plastic sack. He unscrews the top and drops three drops under his tongue with a glass pipette. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: The strongest Indian pain killer you can get. It's for my face. Peter takes Francis' vial and studies it. He unscrews the again. Francis says warily:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Be careful with that. Just take one drop. Peter and Jack drop drops of amber liquid under their ton with the pipette. Francis and Jack each swallow one of Peter's pills. Peter and Francis drink sips of Jack's cou medicine. The gray-haired man observes curiously over the of his newspaper. Two German women at the next table star frowning. Francis reaches into his mouth and digs between two teeth takes out something small and white and sets it on the ed of a plate. It is a false tooth. Peter and Jack look repu and confused. Francis reaches toward the bowl of nuts but hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I also lost a tooth. Jack picks up the false tooth off the edge of the plate. examines it. He reaches into his pocket and pulls out a t folded-up sheaf of pages. He says to Francis and Peter:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You want to read a short story I wrote in France?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) How long is it?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Never mind. Forget it. Peter takes the sheaf of pages. He unfolds it and starts reading. Jack hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You can save it until after dinner, if you want. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  11. Peter shakes his head and continues reading. Francis puts tooth back into his mouth. Peter sees this. He leans forw and says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Maybe right before whenever you're about to take out your tooth, you should say something like, “Please, forgive this.” Because it's, actually, kind of -- Francis recoils slightly, putting his hand to his face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Can you back away a little? You just spit in my eye. Peter looks offended. The German women start arguing loud Peter looks at them and frowns. He squints, mutters, and his temples. He resumes reading the short story. Francis to Jack:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: When was the last time you were in America, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't know. The funeral.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: In other words, a year. Jack shrugs. Francis shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I have to tell you, I support this relationship not working out. Jack nods. Peter laughs suddenly without looking up from short story. Jack looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What part are you on?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Nothing. It just reminded me of something not related to it. Jack looks slightly disappointed. The waiter comes over t the table with a tray of whiskey highballs. He serves the and says: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: May I take your order, please? Francis flips open his menu and says immediately:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Let's see. Do we want meat or fish? I'm going to have the chicken. Jack, you want to try the fish? I bet that's delicious. And Peter? The lamb? A chicken, a fish, and a lamb? How does that sound? Silence. Francis continues:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Who wants a soup? Raise your hand. Francis raises his hand. Peter and Jack reluctantly raise their hands, too. Francis looks at Peter curiously.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Your glasses are crooked. Peter adjusts his sunglasses slightly. They are still crooked. Francis frowns. He points at Peter's face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Are those Dad's?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Yeah. Francis reaches across the table and takes Peter's sungla off. He puts them on himself. He squints.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: You've still got his prescription in here. How can you see in these? Francis returns the sunglasses to Peter and says to the waiter:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Three soups. The grey-haired man looks up from his newspaper and order Hindi. The waiter goes away. Peter says calmly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can you not order for me, please? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  13.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (hesitates) What?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Order for yourself. Peter resumes reading the short story. Francis asks him:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: How's Alice? Peter stops reading but does not look up. He says softly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She's fine. She started a company making these little clay pots. They're, actually, kind of popular. We sent you one.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Thanks! Jack sees the stewardess come out of the kitchen carrying broom and a dustpan. She starts sweeping up some broken crackers off the floor. She sees Jack looking at her. She hesitates. Her lips part. Jack's eyes sharpen, and he sit straight. He says to himself:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want that stewardess. Francis turns around and stares at the stewardess. The tw German women start arguing again. Peter gestures toward t and says under his breath:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: These Germans are bothering me. Peter immediately turns to the women and says aggressivel

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Ladies! The women turn quickly to Peter, startled.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Please, keep it down. Lower your voices, thank you. The women look offended but intimidated. Silence. Francis says abstractly, hopefully: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  14.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Did I raise us? Kind of. Peter and Jack stare at Francis, surprised. They shrug an nod slightly, vaguely positive. Francis nods. The chief steward walks by carrying a tray of empty glasses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Hang on. I'm just going to ask this guy if he can get me a power adaptor. Francis stands up and walks quickly after the chief stewa Peter squints, mutters, and rubs his temples.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She's pregnant. Alice.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Really? You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (uncertainly) How long?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Seven-and-a-half months.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (surprised) It’s going to be born in six weeks or something?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I think so. I'm trying not to get too caught up in it right now. Jack looks puzzled. Peter sees Francis on his way back th table. He says quickly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Don't tell Francis. Jack hesitates. Francis says as he sits down:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Brendan got the wrong voltage. The waiter arrives with four bowls of soup on a tray. Fra says significantly: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10 15.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Please, forgive this. Francis reaches into his mouth, takes out his false tooth and sets it on the edge of his plate.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: am. Peter folds up the sheaf of pages and puts it into his pocket. Francis and Jack stare at him. Peter says finally

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is it supposed to be sad?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (tentatively) I think so.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not crazy about the part where I start screaming at the mechanic. That never happened.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (hesitates) The characters are all fictional. The waiter comes over and sweeps a large number of crumbs bits of food off the tablecloth with a little tool and sa

dialogues.text: Would you care for any dessert? Francis flips open his menu again and says immediately:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Let's see. Do we want sweets or fruit? I'm going to have the pudding. Jack, you want to try the cake? And Peter? What looks good to you? The cookies? Peter does not respond. dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hello, Brendan.

dialogues.text: I wonder what he looks like under all that tape and everything? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18.

dialogues.text: Well, I don't know about his face, but I think his brain might be pretty traumatized. Emotionally, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: How's everything going back there?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Pretty good.

dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I never heard back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (annoyed) So try again. What are you waiting for?

He turns ov and looks out the window, too. Jack stands at a public telephone stand on the other side of the platform listeni with the receiver to his ear and a blank expression on hi face. dialogues.text: No one. He got the code to his ex- girlfriend's answering machine, and he's checking her messages. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  26.

dialogues.text: (hurt) What? When did he confide that to you?

dialogues.text: Just now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Why am I not a part of this? Peter shrugs. Jack hangs up the telephone and pays the attendant. He walks across the platform to the train. Fra whispers:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I never liked that girl.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Me, neither. Anyway, I never trusted her. Francis nods. The compartment door slides open. Jack come inside and shuts it behind him. He looks sad, confused, a highly emotional. He says quietly in the darkness:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't feel good about myself. Jack kneels suddenly to the floor and digs between two suitcases. He stands up again with his hands cupped, pull open the window, and thrusts a cricket fluttering into th air. It flies away under the lights of the platform, off the distance. dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Let's make another agreement: on the spiritual journey, it's crucial that we don't splinter into factions or not include somebody who has advice and might know better. Can we agree to that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.text: Good. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  27.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Is that her?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: How'd she gain access to your personal belongings?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She came to see me in France for twenty- four hours. Francis sighs and shakes his head. Peter says bluntly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Could she be gaslighting you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (hesitates) What's gaslighting?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Let's make another agreement: from now on, if you want to talk to her -- or check her messages -—- you talk to us, first. Anytime, day or night. Can we agree to that? Jack nods. Francis points at the bottle of perfume.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I think we should destroy that. Jack looks at the bottle of perfume. dialogues.text: Rubby?

He digs among stacks of novels, a dictionary, pens, pencils, notebooks, a flashli bottles of water, a camera, and piles of clothes. He find his can of pepper spray. Francis holds his cane around Peter's neck in a strict headlock, squeezing vigorously while Peter’s face turns bright red. Peter digs his fingers under the bandages on Francis’ head. The two brothers buck fitfully on the floo banging into things, shouting, and grunting.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: You don't love me!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes, I do!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I love you, too, but I'm going to mace you in the face! Francis and Peter ignore Jack and continue fighting. Jack takes a deep breath and holds it. He fires the pepper spr at his brothers. It makes a pop and hisses. Silence. Francis and Peter erupt into crazed screaming, pawing at their eyes and gasping for breath. Jack looks pained and scared. Francis grabs at Jack’s ankles. Jack throws open the compartment door and retreats into the corridor. He watches as Francis and Peter slowly stagger their feet, coughing and wheezing. Francis looks at Jack, squinting. Jack says frozen:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I had to do it. Francis lunges at Jack. Jack kicks him. He runs to the en the car, throws open the door, and heads into the next co Jack turns around to face the door. He takes a step backwards. He inserts a fresh capsule into his can of pep spray. He raises the cannister and waits. The door opens, Jack maces Francis and Peter again. Francis and Peter scr and choke, clawing at their eyes. Jack shouts:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Stop including me! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  38 56. Jack turns and sprints away. He runs past the two German women, who look out from their compartment doorway, angry frightened. He opens the door at the end of the car and r into the next coach. He slams full-speed into the sliding glass door to the dining room and blasts though it, shattering glass everywhere. The passengers at their tables are taken aback and stare Jack, stunned. Some people have on party hats. A banner hanging from the ceiling reads Welcome Gala! There are streamers and balloons everywhere. Jack lies on his back the floor, covered with glittering shards and splinters. The chief steward strides toward Jack from the other end the dining car with an icy look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is stopped at a deserted station. The doors to ticket office are closed and padlocked. Francis, Peter, a Jack stand on the platform next to their luggage in a lar pile. Their suitcases are partly unlatched, and bits of clothes stick out of them. A laundry bag has been hastily filled with shoes, books, toiletries, etc. Francis and Pe have brightly bloodshot eyes which they blink and squint, rubbing them continuously. Tears continue to stream down their faces. They wheeze. Francis' false tooth is now missing. (NOTE: it is never replaced.) Two porters in red turbans come out of the train and stac the printer and laminating machine with the luggage. Bren comes out after them wearing a bathrobe and carrying two duffel bags. He looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: The next train's in twenty-four hours. I'll find us a hotel. This came in. Brendan hands Francis a bright yellow envelope.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Why are your eyes all red? Francis frowns. He snaps bitterly:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Why is your head so bald? Brendan recoils. He says quietly, disappointed:

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Because I have alopecia. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  57.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Yeah, I know. That's like albino, right?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Not really. Peter shakes his head in disgust. Francis points at Jack says to Brendan:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Jack maced us. Brendan nods. He stares at Francis for a long minute. He reaches into his pocket, takes out a small, plastic, electrical adapter with three large, brass prongs, and ha it to Francis. He turns away and gets back on the train w his duffel bags. Francis stares down at the adapter in hi hand. He says, worried:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Was I just mean to Brendan?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (with contempt) He's not coming back. He just quit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (sadly) He did, didn't he? The chief steward appears in the open doorway and looks o from the train. His eyes are cold. Francis yells desperat

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Can we at least get our snake back?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF STEWARD
dialogues.text: It's dead.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (horrified) You killed him? The chief steward shrugs. Peter throws his hands up in th air, wounded. The chief steward slams the door shut and p the latch closed. Francis grits his teeth and whacks the with his cane. Peter sees the two German women watching f their open window. One of them says:

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Shame on you. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  58. Peter clenches his fists and looks like he is about to explode. He stammers:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Krauts! The German women close their window coolly, unfazed. Jack says to Francis:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Your fake tooth's gone. Francis checks the gap in his mouth with his finger. He mutters:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Fuck. Jack walks alongside the train to the next coach. Rita si looking out the window with her arms draped over the windowsill. She has tears all over her face.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Did you get maced, too?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, I'm crying. Rita hands Jack a small, paper sack. She looks to Francis Peter. They look back at her blankly. She says to Jack:

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (pause) Let me think about that. I'1l tell you the next time I see you.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (withdrawing) Sure. Tell me then.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (genuinely) Thanks for using me. Rita looks puzzled. She smiles sadly:

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're welcome. Jack nods. Rita stares at Jack. The train starts to move. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  59.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Rita. Jack turns and walks away. Francis yells:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: So long, Sweet Lime! The train begins to pick up speed. Peter picks up a rock throws it at one of the cars. Francis and Jack pick up mo rocks and pelt the train repeatedly. Frightened passenger watch from their windows. The train pulls away, out of th station. Francis, Peter, and Jack see the old man from th train standing at the other end of the platform. A red ca pulls up to the station and honks its horn. Francis, Pete and Jack hesitate. The old man quickly gets into the car. says something to the driver in Hindi. He looks briefly a Francis, Peter, and Jack and pulls away, spitting gravel. Francis, Peter, and Jack stand alone on the platform. Crickets chirp. Francis opens the yellow envelope and tak out a piece of paper and unfolds it. Peter and Jack look it over his shoulder. It is a typewritten letter. Francis reads out loud:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Dear boys -- The platform lights automatically switch off with a clack Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. POTATO FIELD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Francis, Peter, and Jack walk on a rutted dirt road in th dark lugging all their baggage. Jack rolls his trunk behi him. Francis pushes a small trolley with the printer and laminating machine stacked on it and secured with string. Peter carries two suitcases on his head. They carefully c a narrow board over a dry ditch. Francis stares at the le as they walk. A woman reads in VOICE-OVER:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- bad timing! This morning I received the details of your travel plans ina document sent to me from a man named Brendan. Francis passes the letter to Peter. The woman's voice continues:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, I cannot receive you now. A neighboring village requires our urgent (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  60.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: care and assistance due to an emergency, not to mention delays in the construction of our guest quarters and the recent arrival of a man-eating tiger. Peter passes the letter to Jack. The woman's voice contin

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Also, frankly, there is not much to eat. I suggest you come in the spring when you will be safe with me. You must know how sad I am to experience this long separation. I am yearning to see my boys. Jack passes the letter back to Francis. The woman's voice continues:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I hope you will eventually understand and forgive me. God bless you and keep you with Mary's benevolent guidance and the light of Christ's enduring grace. All my love, your mother, Sister Patricia Whitman. Francis folds up the piece of paper and puts it into his pocket. He says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: That sounds like bullshit to me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: She's trying to sell us a vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, Peter, and Jack sit on their suitcases around a small fire made from sticks and garbage. Jack looks insid the paper sack. He takes out a foil packet of cocktail nu and crackers labelled Savory Snack and a bottle of airlin gin and hands them to Francis. He takes out a foil packet chocolates and caramels labelled Sweet Snack and a bottle airline vodka and hands them to Peter. He opens a bottle airline Grand Marnier and downs it in one sip. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Let's get high. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  61. Peter and Jack nod. Francis takes out one of his vials of amber liquid. They each drop three drops under their tong with the pipette. Peter says suddenly with his voice chok up:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Francis looks surprised. He nods and says with feeling:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I wasn't trying to aim for your face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. It's already demolished. Let's go home. Peter nods. Francis continues sadly:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: She doesn't want to see us, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (disappointed) You don't think so? Not even on some primordial level?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (softly) No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: She's been disappearing all our lives. We weren't raised to be treated like that. It's just not done.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe this is how it's supposed to happen. It could all be part of it. Maybe this is where the spiritual journey ends. Pause. Francis suddenly grabs his briefcase, snaps it ope and takes out the manila envelope. He reaches into it. He pulls out the three peacock feathers. He hands one to Pet and one to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Did you read the instructions? Peter and Jack nod distractedly. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  62.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: OK. Let's do it. Francis, Peter, and Jack each walk away in a different direction, into the darkness, counting fifty paces out lo They stop in the distance. Francis digs in the ground and chants to himself. Peter spins around in a circle three t and kneels down on one knee. Jack throws his feather into air, releasing it with the wind. They clench their fists shout. Francis, Peter, and Jack reconvene around the fire. Jack strangely:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Which direction did yours go?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Your feathers. Mine blew towards the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (appalled) That's not right. It's not supposed to get blown away. You blow on it -- Francis pantomimes blowing on a feather.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: -- then bury it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I didn't get that. I still have mine. Peter holds up his feather. Francis looks frustrated. He says, pained:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: You guys didn't do it right. I asked if you read the instructions. You did it wrong. Francis covers his hands over his eyes and shakes his hea He tries to contain himself. He stammers:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I tried my hardest. I don't know what else to do. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  63. Francis lifts his hands off his eyes. Peter and Jack look him desolately. They sit back down around the fire. Peter takes off his sunglasses and looks at them. He says quiet

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't think Dad would've hated it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (distantly) Well, I'm sure he would've been flattered, anyway -- whether he thought it was in good taste or not.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Did he really say you were his favorite?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (pause) I don't know. I could barely understand him. He wasn't really breathing. Silence. Jack looks up at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I wonder if the three of us could've been friends in real life. Not as brothers, but as people.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (pause) We might've had a better chance, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (brightening desperately) Let's make another agreement: we'll all come back in the spring when the flowers start to --

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (harshly) We're never coming back here. Let's just find an airport and go our separate ways. Jack takes out two airline bottles of rum and cognac and hands them to Francis and Peter. He says wistfully:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it sound great if you could hear a train going by off in the distance right now?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not really. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41 64.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: It'd probably be annoying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daybreak. Francis, Peter, and Jack walk together lugging their baggage along the banks of a fast-rushing river. Francis hits a bump with his trolley. A string snaps, and printer and laminating machine tip off the top of it and smash down onto the ground. Francis, Peter, and Jack paus They look down at the damaged printer and broken laminati machine. They look at each other. The start walking again Francis points:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Look. In the middle of the river, there is a flimsy raft mounte four oil drums with ropes looped under it reaching to the banks. Three boys ride on it. One is ten, one is eight, a one is six. They wear white cloths around their waists an carry large baskets of vegetables. One has a white scarf around his shoulders. They pull the raft across the river through the swift current, on a rope cable stretched in t air over the water. Francis, Peter, and Jack watch them. Jack's says calmly:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's going to tip over. The raft bounces once, a rope snaps, and it flips. The baskets tumble and radishes spill everywhere. The boys fa into the churning water and hang on desperately. Francis, Peter, and Jack watch, shocked. Peter says under his brea

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Go. Francis, Peter, and Jack drop their suitcases, sprint to river, and splash in, wading quickly into the deeper wate Jack loses his footing and starts to get swept away. He reaches out and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Francis! Francis grabs Jack's hand and grips the cable tightly. Pe leads them hand-over-hand along the rope. The three boys cling to the upturned raft. They look terrified. Francis yells to Jack:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Grab the little one! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  42 65. Jack scoots along the edge of the raft to the smallest of boys. He grabs the boy's arm and loops it around his neck yells:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don't let go of me! Francis and Peter pull themselves onto the upturned raft crawl over the oil drums to the other two boys on the far side. The raft rocks and tilts. They struggle to balance. Francis tugs the oldest boy out of the water. He and the scramble back across the oil drums to the rope. The current shifts, and the raft flips again, righting itself, with Peter and the middle boy bracing themselves it swings through the air and slams down with a crash. Francis yanks the oldest boy clear and clutches the cable shouts:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Peter! Jack yells from the shallow water, rushing back toward th raft. The youngest boy crouches on the shore behind him, shivering.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What happened? Peter's voice comes from underneath the raft:

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're OK! We're OK!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Peter and the middle boy in a dark space between the oil drums. Peter clutches the boy with one arm and hangs onto slats above with the other. The sound of the rushing wate echoes against the hollow metal. The boy spits as he bobs the water. He tugs on a scarf wrapped around him, knotted twisted, caught on one of the oil drums. Peter jerks at i He says as he tries to tear the cloth:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Do you speak English? The boy nods with his eyes wide, trembling and terrified.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Great! I'll be right back! I'm going see what's got you! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  43 66. Peter ducks underwater. The boy's eyes dart around nervou Peter resurfaces. He says, smiling warmly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You've got yourself all tangled up, don't you, pal? Well, I'm going to get you out of this! Sit tight! Peter starts ripping away at the tangled fabric. He tries make conversation:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How old are you? The boy does not respond. Peter continues:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Are you guys brothers? The boy does not answer. Peter pulls at a hunk of wire, straining to break the boy free.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don't want to say anything? (pause) Well, here's an icebreaker: my wife's pregnant! She's going to have a baby! Can you believe that? I'm scared! The boy laughs. Peter laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Francis hanging onto Jack's hand, reaching toward the raf while Jack grips the cable with his other hand. The oldes boy clings to Jack with his arms around his neck. Francis shouts to Peter:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Why are you still under there? Peter yells something undecipherable from beneath the raf The rope slackens with a jolt. Jack turns quickly. The po that the cable is attached to bends slowly. Jack watches, frozen. He says to himself curiously:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's stretching. On the far shore, a knot around a tree breaks, and the ro snaps free. The raft shoots away, spinning. Francis shout Jack: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  67.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Hang on! Francis and Jack grip the broken cable as they are swept downstream until the rope jerks taut. They whirl into a tangle of reeds and branches at the shore with the oldest boy. They watch the raft careening into the distance. Pet surfaces for an instant, gasping and swimming desperately try to stop the raft. He goes under again. The raft bumps the rapids and disappears suddenly over a bank of rocks. Francis and Jack race up to the dirt road and bolt down t river after Peter. They look freaked out. Francis grimace and hops a step on his bad leg. The other boys run after them. Jack sprints ahead, hurtling and sliding in the bru They run one full minute without a word. Jack snaps from bramble and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Peter! Peter wades from the shallow water below, holding the mid boy tightly in his arms. Planks of the demolished raft an smashed oil drums float behind them. Blood rushes freely Peter's scalp and flows over the entire side of his face. boy's arms hang limp, and the wet cloth over his body is with blood. Jack screams back to Francis:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's all bloody! Jack starts down the embankment and falls, rolling over t gravel. He picks himself up by the river and splashes out Peter. Francis and the other two boys catch up in the background. Peter shakes his head and says rapidly, matte fact:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He's dead. He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (blankly) He's dead?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The rocks killed him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're bleeding like crazy. Jack presses his hand against a laceration above Peter's temple. Francis yells as he approaches: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  44 45 68.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Peter! You're OK!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I didn't save mine. Everyone gathers around Peter, breathing hard. They look the dead boy. Peter looks to the oldest boy and asks:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, Peter, and Jack walk across the scrub, past bony grazing cows, with the two surviving boys. They are drenc and Peter is bloody. He carries the dead boy on his shoul A group of old women holding baskets of grain stop and st An small man with a wheelbarrow begins to walk alongside them, curious and concerned. Children gather, chattering nervously. Francis, Peter, and Jack reach the edge of a village. The are thatched huts and clay brick houses. Agitated people out to meet them, yelling in Hindi. More voices shout in distance. Dogs circle. A large man with a thick moustache and a horrified look o his face rushes up to Peter, shouting. He lifts the dead away, into his arms. He says something rapidly and grimac He is the father. He dashes into the village followed by two surviving boys and most of the bystanders. Francis, Peter, and Jack are left standing with the small and some other children, who all stare at them. A teenage boy in a school uniform of a red shirt and orange pants s something loudly to them in Hindi and darts off. Francis, Peter, and Jack look at each other, weary and lost. The teenaged boy comes back quickly carrying a metal pot fill with water. He offers it to them. Francis, Peter, and Jac share a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, open room on a courtyard. Brightly colored cards depicting deities and mythological scenes are tacked to t walls. Francis, Peter, Jack, and the two surviving boys s on the dirt floor at a low table. They wear white cloths wrapped around them, and Peter has a large bandage taped the side of his forehead. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  46 47 69. Numerous people come in and out of the room and cross bus through the courtyard speaking to each other in Hindi and shaking hands with and bowing to Francis, Peter, and Jack Everyone stares at them continuously with kind eyes. Wome saris attend to them, pouring cups of tea and serving bow of rice. A thin, smiling man drapes white towels over the shoulders. A tall man in a long, white shirt and glasses comes into room and walks through carrying a black doctor's bag. He bald and has a white beard. He opens the door to the next courtyard. There are chaotic shouts and continual, intens sobbing. He goes out and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis', Peter's, and Jack's suits, shirts, and socks ha drying from a clothesline outside. Five men in loin-cloth arrive with Francis', Peter's, and Jack's luggage, carryi the bags and suitcases on their heads and pulling the tru in a wagon. Francis lies on his back on a mat on the ground. Crouchin children stare down at him. A woman in a yellow sari holds a sleeping baby with its h sticking up funny. The baby's hand grips Peter's finger. Three men stand next to them, watching. One of them says something quietly in Hindi. The mother offers the baby fo Peter to hold. Peter breathes slowly as he takes the baby cradles it into his arms. Others gather closer. Peter loo up at the mother. He seems moved and dazed. Jack sits in the grass with three girls helping them stri flowers together in long strands. One of them picks up a beetle off the ground and throws it. In the next courtyard, the dead boy lies on a rug on the ground in front of a hut with a sheet over the lower half his body. With the help of two other men, the father pour water over the boy's neck and chest and washes his skin w a sponge. Another man sits on the floor binding bamboo po together with lengths of rope to make the frame of a stretcher. A young woman kneels on the ground, watching. She is in shock. She is the mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, Peter, and Jack wait with their luggage stacked large pile at the side of a dirt highway. They wear their suits again. The teenaged boy in the school uniform stand Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  48 49 70. next to them. He has a pink handkerchief in his shirt poc Silence. Peter turns to the boy and says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can you explain that I almost had him? The boy hesitates. He stares at Peter curiously. Peter continues:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I lost him when we went off the rocks -- he was too slippery -- but I had him the whole rest of the time. (with a lump in his throat) I want them to know that. The boy says something in Hindi. Peter nods. A bus appears in the distance. The boy steps into the roa and whips the handkerchief out of his pocket. He waves it the air. The bus approaches and comes to a stop. It is decorated and personalized with colorful, hand-painted st flowers, and patterns which cover it entirely. cur TO: 48 Francis, Peter, and Jack at the top of a ladder attached the back of the bus. Several young passengers riding on t roof help them strap their trunk and suitcases to a lugga platform. A sign painted above the rear bumper reads Horn Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, Peter, and Jack climb into the crowded bus and w toward the back. The other passengers hold bundles of fab bags of grain, etc. They all stare from their seats as Francis, Peter, and Jack make their way down the aisle to back. Francis, Peter, and Jack jam their hand-baggage into an overhead rack. A young man with two earrings quickly move patched up, old, cardboard box out of the way, and they squeeze into their seats. A skinny, old man in a multi- colored turban smiles at Francis brightly. Francis waves hello and nods wearily. The old man asks politely:

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing in this place? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  50 71.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (distantly) Well, originally, I guess we came here on a spiritual journey -- but that didn't really pan out. The old man nods seriously. The bus driver closes the doo He puts the bus in gear, honks the horn, and hits the gas The two surviving boys run into the road in front of the waving their arms and yelling urgently. The teenaged boy the school uniform runs behind them fluttering his pink handkerchief. The bus driver honks again and stomps on th brakes. The bus lurches to a stop. The driver throws the doors open. The two surviving boys poke their heads insid and exchange words rapidly in Hindi with the driver. The driver looks to the back of the bus. He points to Francis. Francis stands up and walks quickly to the front the bus. Peter, Jack, and everyone else on-board watch as Francis, the driver, and the two surviving boys speak in hushed voices. Francis nods. He walks back down the aisle kneels down on one knee. Peter and Jack lean in close to

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: We're invited to the funeral. Pause. Peter and Jack stand up. Francis helps them take t bags back down from the overhead rack. Everyone watches a they make their way to the front of the bus and exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis, Peter, and Jack come out of a hut. They are dres in their white pajamas and rabbit slippers. They walk pas three-wheeled flat-bed truck as two men in white tunics approach carrying the body of the dead boy. It is strappe the bamboo stretcher and wrapped in white silk with strin of flowers all over it. The men place it on the back of t truck. Francis, Peter, and Jack pick up some stray flower off the ground and add them to the pile on the body.
